'''Monero''' ('''XMR''') is an open-source [[cryptocurrency]] created in April 2014 that focuses on [[fungibility]], [[privacy]] and [[decentralization]]. Monero uses an [[Obfuscation|obfuscated]] public [[ledger]], meaning anybody can broadcast or send transactions, but no outside observer can tell the source, amount or destination.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/shortcuts/2017/dec/11/missed-bitcoin-boom-five-more-baffling-cryptocurrencies-to-blow-your-savings-on|title=Missed the bitcoin boom? Five more baffling cryptocurrencies to blow your savings on|last=Hern|first=Alex|date=2017-12-11|work=The Guardian|access-date=2018-12-11|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> Monero uses a [[Proof-of-work system|Proof of Work]] mechanism to issue new coins and incentivize miners to secure the network and validate transactions.

The privacy afforded by Monero has attracted use by people interested in evading law enforcement during events such as the [[WannaCry ransomware attack|WannaCry Ransomware Attack]], or on the dark web buying illegal substances.<ref name=ArsWanna>{{cite news |last1=Gallagher |first1=Sean |title=Researchers say WannaCry operator moved bitcoins to "untraceable" Monero |url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2017/08/researchers-say-wannacry-operator-moved-bitcoins-to-untraceable-monero/ |work=Ars Technica |date=4 August 2017 |language=en-us}}</ref><ref name=WIREDFire>{{Cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/2017/01/monero-drug-dealers-cryptocurrency-choice-fire/ |title=Monero, the Drug Dealer's Cryptocurrency of Choice, Is on Fire |work=WIRED|access-date=2017-11-22 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/jpgv8k/monero-cryptocurrency-dark-net-drug-dealers-hope-more-anonymous-than-bitcoin-alphabay|title=Meet Monero, the Currency Dark Net Dealers Hope Is More Anonymous Than Bitcoin|date=2016-08-23|work=Motherboard|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-us}}</ref> Despite this, Monero is actively encouraged to those seeking financial privacy, since payments and account balances remain entirely hidden, which is not the standard for most cryptocurrencies.<ref>{{cite news |last=Somerset Webb |first=Merryn |date=2018-03-23 |title=Trust is in increasingly short supply for investors |url=https://www.ft.com/content/0356d7fe-2dea-11e8-a34a-7e7563b0b0f4 |work=Financial Times |access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref>

== Architecture ==
[[File:Monero GUI 0.12.3.0.png|thumb|left|Monero GUI 0.12.3.0 on Windows 10]]

Unlike many cryptocurrencies that are derivatives of Bitcoin, Monero is based on the CryptoNight [[Proof-of-work system|proof-of-work]] [[hash algorithm]], which comes from the [[CryptoNote]] protocol.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/manufacturer-holds-cryptonight-asic-firesale-200840436.html|title=Manufacturer Holds Cryptonight ASIC Firesale after Monero Hard Forks|website=ca.finance.yahoo.com|language=en-CA|access-date=2018-12-11}}</ref> 

The CryptoNote protocol possesses significant algorithmic differences relating to [[Blockchain (database)|blockchain]] [[obfuscation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/monero-headed-18k-ripple-price-224003501.html|title=Monero Headed to $18k, Ripple Price Primed for 97% Crash: Research|website=ca.finance.yahoo.com|language=en-CA|access-date=2018-12-11}}</ref>

In particular, the [[ring signature]]s mix the spender's input with a group of others, making it exponentially more difficult to establish a link between each subsequent transaction.<ref name=WIREDFire />

Additionally, "stealth addresses" generated for each transaction make it impossible to discover the actual destination address of a transaction by anyone else other than the sender and the receiver.<ref name=CourtoisMercer2017>{{cite journal |last1=Courtois |first1=Nicolas T. |last2=Mercer |first2=Rebekah |date=2017 |title=Stealth Address and Key Management Techniques in Blockchain Systems |url=http://www.scitepress.org/Papers/2017/62700/62700.pdf |journal=Proceedings of the 3rd International Conference on Information Systems Security and Privacy (ICISSP) |volume= |issue= |pages=559–566 |doi=10.5220/0006270005590566 |access-date=2017-07-24 | isbn=978-989-758-209-7 | publisher=SCITEPRESS – Science and Technology Publications, Lda.}}</ref> Finally, the "ring confidential transactions" mechanism hides the transferred amount.<ref name=NoetherMackenzie2016>{{cite journal |last1=Noether |first1=Shen |last2=Mackenzie |first2=Adam | last3=the Monero Research Lab |date=21 December 2016 |title=Ring Confidential Transactions |url=http://ledgerjournal.org/ojs/index.php/ledger/article/view/34 |journal=Ledger |volume=1 |number=0 |pages=1–18 |doi=10.5195/ledger.2016.34 |issn=2379-5980 |access-date=2018-08-03}}</ref><ref name=WIREDFire />

Monero is designed to be resistant to [[application-specific integrated circuit]] (ASIC) mining, which is commonly used to mine other cryptocurrencies such as [[Bitcoin]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/business/2018/05/19/how-a-few-companies-are-bitcoining-it|title=How a few companies are bitcoining it|date=2018-05-19|work=The Economist|access-date=2018-12-11|issn=0013-0613}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/dec/13/video-site-visitors-unwittingly-mine-cryptocurrency-as-they-watch-report-openload-streamango-rapidvideo-onlinevideoconverter-monero|title=Billions of video site visitors unwittingly mine cryptocurrency as they watch|last=Gibbs|first=Samuel|date=2017-12-13|work=The Guardian|access-date=2018-12-11|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> It can be mined somewhat efficiently on consumer grade hardware such as [[x86]], [[x86-64]], [[ARM architecture|ARM]] and [[GPU]]s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/12/19/16796084/backdoor-coin-mining-hacks-are-spreading-as-prices-rise|title=Backdoor coin-mining hacks are spreading as prices rise|last=Brandom|first=Russell|date=2017-12-19|website=The Verge|access-date=2018-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/cyber-attackers-are-cashing-in-on-cryptocurrency-mining-but-heres-why-theyre-avoiding-bitcoin/|title=Cyber attackers are cashing in on cryptocurrency mining - but here's why they're avoiding bitcoin|last=Palmer|first=Danny|website=ZDNet|language=en|access-date=2018-12-11}}</ref>

== History ==
In 2014 Bitcointalk forum user known as thankful_for_today forked the codebase of Bytecoin into the name BitMonero, which is a compound of [[Bit]] (as in [[Bitcoin]]) and Monero (literally meaning "coin" in [[Esperanto]]).<ref name="WIREDFire" /> The release of BitMonero was very poorly received by the community that initially backed it. Plans to fix and improve Bytecoin with changes to block time, tail emission and block reward had all been ignored, and thankful_for_today simply disappeared from the development scene. A group of users led by Johnny Mnemonic decided that the community should take over the project, and five days later they did while also changing the name to Monero.

Due to its privacy features, Monero experienced rapid growth in [[market capitalization]] and transaction volume during the year 2016, faster and bigger than any other cryptocurrency that year. This growth was driven by its uptake in the [[darknet market]], where people used it to buy stolen credit cards, guns, and drugs.<ref name=WIREDFire /> Two major darknet markets were shut down in July 2017 by law enforcement.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Popper |first1=Nathaniel |last2=Ruiz |first2=Rebecca R. |title=2 Leading Online Black Markets Are Shut Down by Authorities |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/20/business/dealbook/alphabay-dark-web-opioids.html?_r=0 |work=The New York Times |date=20 July 2017}}</ref>  From the beginning, Monero has been used by people holding other cryptocurrencies like [[Bitcoin]] to break the link between transactions, with the other cryptocoins first converted to Monero, then after some delay converted back and sent to an address unrelated to those used before.

On January 10, 2017, the privacy of Monero transactions was further strengthened by the adoption of Bitcoin Core developer Gregory Maxwell's algorithm ''Confidential Transactions'', hiding the amounts being transacted, in combination with an improved version of ''Ring Signatures''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/03/12/bittercoin-true-blockchain-believers-vs-the-trough-of-disillusionment/|title=Bittercoin: true blockchain believers versus the trough of disillusionment|website=TechCrunch|language=en-US|access-date=2018-12-19}}</ref>

After many online payment platforms shut down access for [[white nationalists]] following the [[Unite the Right rally]] in 2017, some of them, including [[Christopher Cantwell]] and [[weev|Andrew Auernheimer]] ("weev"), started using and promoting Monero.<ref name=NewsweekCite>{{cite news |last1=Hayden |first1=Michael Edison |title=White supremacists are investing in a cryptocurrency that promises to be completely untraceable |url=https://www.newsweek.com/white-supremacists-cryptocurrency-monero-bitcoin-861104 |work=Newsweek |date=27 March 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref name=MotherboardCite>{{cite news |last1=Cox |first1=Joseph |title=Neo-Nazis Turn to Privacy-Focused Cryptocurrency Monero |url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/neqy7z/neo-nazis-monero-weev-daily-stormer |work=Motherboard |date=5 March 2018 |language=en-us}}</ref>

The operators behind the May 2017 global ransomware incident [[WannaCry]] converted their proceeds into Monero.<ref name=ArsWanna />  In June, [[The Shadow Brokers]], the group that leaked the code used in WannaCry, started accepting payments in Monero.<ref name=ArsWanna />

Malicious hackers have previously embedded Monero mining code into websites and apps seeking profit for themselves.<ref name="ZDNetApps">{{Cite news |url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/android-security-coin-miners-show-up-in-apps-and-sites-to-wear-out-your-cpu/ |title=Android security: Coin miners show up in apps and sites to wear out your CPU {{!}} ZDNet|last=Tung|first=Liam|work=ZDNet|access-date=2017-11-22|language=en}}</ref> In late 2017 malware and antivirus service providers blocked a [[JavaScript]] implementation of Monero miner Coinhive that was embedded in websites and apps, in some cases by hackers.  Coinhive generated the script as an alternative to advertisements; a website or app could embed it, and use website visitor's [[CPU]] to mine the cryptocurrency while the visitor is consuming the content of the webpage, with the site or app owner getting a percentage of the mined coins.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2017/10/19/malwarebytes_blocking_coin_hive_browser_cryptocurrency_miner_after_user_revolt/ |work=The Register |title=Stealth web crypto-cash miner Coinhive back to the drawing board as blockers move in |date=October 19, 2017 |last=Thomson |first=Iain}}</ref> Some websites and apps did this without informing visitors, and some hackers implemented it in way that drained visitors' CPUs. As a result the script was blocked by companies offering [[ad blocking]] subscription lists, antivirus services, and antimalware services.<ref name=ArsCPU>{{Cite news |url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2017/10/a-surge-of-sites-and-apps-are-exhausting-your-cpu-to-mine-cryptocurrency/ |title=A surge of sites and apps are exhausting your CPU to mine cryptocurrency |work=Ars Technica |date=October 30, 2017 |language=en-us |last=Goodin |first=Dan}}</ref><ref name=ZDNetApps />

In January 2018, Bloomberg suggested the hackers who stole approximately 500 million [[NEM (cryptocurrency)|NEM tokens]] ($530 million) from [[Coincheck]] would find it challenging to launder the stolen tokens by selling them for Monero since at least one exchange, [[ShapeShift|Shapeshift]], had blocked NEM addresses associated with the theft.

In the first half of 2018, Monero was used in 44% of cryptocurrency [[ransomware]] attacks.<ref name="cnbc">{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/07/1-point-1b-in-cryptocurrency-was-stolen-this-year-and-it-was-easy-to-do.html |title=$1.1 billion in cryptocurrency has been stolen this year, and it was apparently easy to do |last=Rooney |first=Kate |date=2018-06-07 |work=CNBC |access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref>

In July 2018, the Change.org Foundation took advantage of Monero's mining network by creating a screensaver that mines Monero to raise funds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/change-org-launches-screensaver-mines-220303080.html|title=Change.org Launches Screensaver That Mines Monero for Charity|last=Wilmoth|first=Josiah|date=2018-07-18|work=Yahoo! Finance|access-date=2018-09-20|language=en-US}}</ref> In November that same year, Bail Bloc released a mobile app that mines Monero to raise funds for low-income defendants who can't otherwise cover their own [[Bail|cash bail]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/radio/spark/379-integrated-shopping-leaving-silicon-valley-wifi-enabled-plastic-and-more-1.4474658/mining-cryptocurrency-helps-raise-bail-for-those-who-can-t-1.4474674|title=Mining cryptocurrency helps raise bail for those who can't {{!}} CBC Radio|work=CBC|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/vb3j93/you-can-now-mine-cryptocurrency-to-bail-people-out-of-jail-bail-bloc|title=You Can Now Mine Cryptocurrency to Bail People Out of Jail|date=2017-11-15|work=Motherboard|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cointelegraph.com/news/us-crypto-initiative-donates-monero-to-bail-out-immigrants-in-ice-detention|title=US: Crypto Initiative Donates Monero to Bail Out Immigrants in ICE Detention|last=Alexandre|first=Ana|date=2018-11-17|work=Cointelegraph|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en}}</ref>

== Transaction linkability ==
In April 2017 research highlighted three major threats to Monero users' privacy. The first relies on leveraging the ring signature size of zero, and ability to see the output amounts.<ref name=singapore_paper>{{cite web |first1=Amrit |last1=Kumar |first2=Clément |last2=Fischer |first3=Shruti |last3=Tople |first4=Prateek |last4=Saxena |title=A Traceability Analysis of Monero’s Blockchain |url=https://eprint.iacr.org/2017/338.pdf |website=eprint.iacr.org |accessdate=6 November 2017}}</ref> The second, described as "Leveraging Output Merging", involves tracking transactions where two outputs belong to the same user,<ref name="singapore_paper" /> such as when a user is sending the funds to himself ("churning"). Finally the third threat, "Temporal Analysis", shows that predicting the right output in a ring signature could potentially be easier than previously thought.<ref name="singapore_paper" />

The Monero development team had addressed the first concern in January 2017, prior to the actual release of the research paper, with the introduction of Ring Confidential Transactions (RingCT) as well as mandating a minimum size of ring signatures in the March 2016 protocol upgrade. Monero developers also noted that Monero Research Labs, their academic and research arm, already noted and outlined the deficiency in two public research papers in 2014 and 2015.
